Washington D.C.9
Dear Mother.
In the city of our country I will write you a few lines. I wrote you from the car, the Penn. Limited. hope you have received it. 
I am indeed off for Cuba. Our ship sails from New York Tuesday. I leave Washington to-morrow. 
It hardly seems like Sunday to-day, at 9. this morn I went down to-morrow to.  It hardly seems like Sunday to-day, at 9.   this unclear I went? down to unclear

to the War department to see the Surgeon General. he was not there. is in NY but saw the Chief Clerk Jones. he took my name so as to secure my passage to Santiago. and to-morrow I have to be down to give my oath just like a soldier which inlists. I asked if it was binding - and to what extent. Mr Jones, said "No, You can go when you want to. Just notify us." only we must be true to the cause & obey orders. That seems real soldier like, dont it? & how proud papa would be to know it. Well you see mother I am the one that has fathers war spirit, dont you think I ought to go?

I was met by one of the Daughter of Revolution. and taken to Anita Newcomb McGee's M.D. office and I am her guest while in Washington she is a charming southern lady quite business like. her home is beautiful at Wyoming & Conn. Ave's. Washington is truly beautiful, but I shall not have time to visit any of the buildings now. it is purely business now and I have unclear--hosts? to do. 
The climate is just a little warmer than at Chicago. but cooler than

Baltimor, through which I came yesterday. 
I took the Penn Limited to Harisburg where I changed cars for Washington. 
I rode through Maryland nearly all the way in to Washington and it is a sublimely beautiful state. The chestnut trees grow imense sizes. I will send you the leaf of the Eucalyptus tree (the oil extracted is medicinal) the tree itself gives a beautiful odor. I plucked it in the squar almost oppsite the war dep - an imense building. will write to Esther and give my address so you can write me your Daughter Amy

Washington, D. C. July 18" 1898
Dear Esther:
I am out bound from Wash D.C. at 12 oclock to-night. to-day at 9 A.M. I took oath of office. on my anniversiry the 18th. I am now under the state and flag, promised to serve my country, to be true to the office under which I serve, to protect my country against enemies foreign or &tc all of which I agreed to. three of us were sworn in together - it was impressive - in the presence of Judges &tc one of the form

I do not get but is on file at the War dept - 4 others were made out all signed by myself one copy is my own. I have sent it to Tina to keep secure for me. that entitles me to pension &tc - as guest of Dr Anita Newcomb McGee I have been right royally served. She is charming, and southern as she is, is a thorough business woman You do not know how the life of the city throbs with war. Congress is adjourned, but

there is life and hustle
among Military men &
the War dep is pulsing with work - every
office & sub office is
crowded to its capacity
with Clerks in the
service of this war. it
is nothing to see squads
of troops marching and
officers hurrying to & fro.
they are a grand set of
men with their military
bearing. - (papa had it to
perfection.) no wonder
army men are so gallant,
there are bred gentlemen.
Every where I and my

sister nurses have met with
courtesy, and men of note
have desired to shake 
my hand in a common
cause, it is worth living
for to be thus valued and able
to serve. We can communicate
with our friends, receive and
send messages.
Address

 Amy Eleanor Wingreen
Contract nurse
Santiago De Cuba
via War Department
Surgeon General's office

Washington D.C.

July 22.  ( to Mother )

 Friday A.M. on board

the Resolute Ex Poste Cuba
Everything along the Gulf
Stream is beautiful, the
water is full of phosphoresence
at night, and such a charming
blue in the day light.

 Yesterday the sailors

fired cannon the target
was barrels and the
first 3 shots hit the
mark there were about
50 shots fired. the cannon
are six inch and six
pound shot. We have
two guns in the front and two
in the aft, they do not
fear for the enemy's

guns or warships those
the captain says there
are some around still
which have not been
captured. I do not know
whether we have passed
San Salvador - no the
porter just came in to
my state room with matter and he
said we pass it this P.M.
We are out of American
waters, or, what used to be
Spanish. It is warm even
in the sea breeze. so 
different from New York -
I should have said that our
crew and captain does not

fear being over taken by the enemy, for
if any should appear we can steam up
at the rate of 20 knots an hour and run away. The
usual speed which we are going at is 15 knots.
in Eva's? letter I said 20 to 25 but I got
that from hear say. The later is correct and
comes from the Captain. The Chaplain is
a very fine man, scotch. McCook, of the
fighting McCooks. he is a Presbyterian
and Sunday we will have services. The Capt.
says we will reach Santiago Monday, we left
N.Y. Tuesday 3.30 P.M.

The voyage has been very
smooth and no one sea sick,
I expected that I might be
yet said from the beginning
that I would not. I have not 
been but do not feel just
comfortable as if I was on 
land. for my first experience
on the ocean I think I am 
doing quite well. Have been
on deck all the time & I must
get there as soon as I can.
have washed out handkerchiefs
and been busy this a.m.

 We sometimes see a

vessel but very few.
our ship is of the Old
Dominion line well
built steel front so that
when the cannon were fired

there was not the least jar
noticible. Our soldiers have
not the smokeless powder
and it is some time before
the smoke clears away. Clouds
of it rolls far out on the ocean.

 We have on board the

"Resolute" about 75 nurses
only about 12 women
there are a few soldiers
going down with us. The
reporter from Leslies Weekly
came on board just before 
we left the pier at N.Y.
to take the nurses - the ladies
I had to go back for a package
which I had expected all
the day on the Adams express

but did not yet. I was only 
informed that the way bill
was lost. so I did not
get the package, nor
my pictures taken.

 I am writing my letter

in a sort of backward
fashion.  It is looking backward
that I am where I 
think of the United States
so please pardon me it
my letter runs in like
fashion.

 I wrote you from the

Car. The Pennsylvania
Limited where they have
typerwriter services among
all the other comforts.  It is
an ideal Route reached
Harrisburg at noon Sat
last Monday 12 at night we left Wash
I do not know when you will receive this but it goes
back to U.S. on the return trip of Resolute. write soon.

when changed cars for Baltimore and Washington
traveled through Maryland and the country
was delightful.  The chestnut trees were
so very large and in bloom. It is quite
stony and many of the older houses were
built from stones and stone fences was a 
great feature. While rail fences was the
first thing in sight coming into Virginia
was charmed with Washington but had no
time for sight seeing. Stopped at the
home of Anita Newcomb McGee and she
made it very pleasant for me.

 Last Monday 12 at night we left Wash

I do not know when you will receive this but it
goes to U.S. on the return trip of Resolute. write soon.

via B. & O.  Reached Jersey
City the next morning at
7 A.M. took the steamer 
to New York where we
went into the Army Building
39 Whitehall St. to get our
transportation. Saw very
little of NY but Broadway
and thought it had
better have been named
Narrow Lane so was dissapointed
There is on board the "Resolute"
several physicians among
them two Cuban doctors. One
is quite noted in yellow
fever & gave me his paper to
read.  Must close for this
time Lovingly yours
Daughter Amy

On board "Resolute:" New York .
July 19 1898  3.30 P.M.
It has come -
The Supreme moment!
All aboard!  the gang
plank removed.

 Going: going: -

Salute from crowds on shore

 "Hurrah! - Hurrah!!-
  Hurrah!!!

Cuba Libre - say the people.
Out from the north shore
pier into the bay, Bedlows
Island to the left, the
people on shore are but a 
small speck in the distance.
We are leaving New York behind,

and are steaming out into the
salt water: not one on the
landing was familiar to me and
strange enough it seemed
not to know a soul. I felt like
a stranger in a strange land
the journey from New York to
Santiago will comprise a
week or more and this is called
a fast boat. The journey
is a much longer one in
mileage than than from New York
to Liverpool.

 A small craft "Ann

Eliza" just saluted us as we
passed her in the bay --
They say the "Resolute" is a ship
captured from the Enemy,
it is about the size of the
"Indiana" beautifully built
and smooth going - as yet
we have not reached the

ocean itself.  Ah there is

  The Brooklyn Bridge!

I said I was disappointed in
New York its streets are
so narrow and one wonders
how the people get by
without jamming out each
others ribs, but they have a 
faculty in New York
for disappearing into snall
space and coming and going
and not jostling their neighbors
That is one feature of
New York which I like.
The harbor is full of ships
which seem to be ready for
action yet the riggings
are all stripped, and no life on
board that seems to be indicative of an
alertness.

 We came into new York from Washington

this A.M. 7 Via the B & O at 6 am

we passed through Philadelphia
then along the Hudson River
into Elizabeth N J and from
Jersey City took the ferry
which steamed us into the
New York landing: Breakfasted
at depot in Jersey City and
did not dine untill on board
the "Resolute" at 1 pm. The
Dinner was very good and satisfying
the service is excellent.
They realize that we as Government
nurses are a desired acquisition
to the nation at this time
and place a value per head
at no small rate according to
all appearances. We nurses
were assigned a table to ourselves,
and we were eight white
women. Anita Newcomb McGee
informed me that several colored -
and in all about 75 counting the
men were going.

some one on board said about 22 men
and one colored woman and we
wight white nurses were about
all there were - the rest may come
later.  600 new cases of yellow
fever are reported from the
New York bulletin boards this
noon.

A picture of the nurses was 

taken on board the ship, but
I could not remain to be taken
as I had some thing which I
expected from the Adams ex-
I have chased all day for it and
finally I asked for an explanation
why it could not be located 
and they coolly told me the
way bill was lost and the
name was not written plainly
on the wrapper. I asked if
they were not responsible

for the transaction of their
business but they said they
could not help it. Was quite
disappointed, for tried hard
enough to get the things I had
hoped for.

 We are going quite

smoothly along, are still in
the bay as they reversed and 
went back after some more of
the passengers who did not
arrive in time at the ships
leaving pier, another smaller
steamer came up and the
sides of the ships were at a
parallel angle when the men
stepped from the small boat
to our "Resolute".

 It is beginning to rain,

but is clearer than it was a
little while ago so it may clear

off and be fair weather yet.

 One of the nurses said she

was disappointed in Washington.
I was quite amazed at that, but
she seemed just as much surprised
when I told of my disappointment 
in New York. I could not
realize that that was all there
was to Broadway, Trinity Church
was fine that came up quite
to my expectation.

 We are steaming out of 

the bay (a little fishing
smack flew the colors as we
passed her.) Statue Island
is a beautiful portion of
land with many imposing working
residences. To think I am
really  and speedily going from
the New York harbor out on

a voyage to what seemed
so distant. An island of red
painted houses, the Arsenal
I believe it is which we are
opposite and an island just
outside of white houses seven
exactly alike.

 The Jersey shore

look very fine in the distance
and soon we will leave land  behind
us; when we see land again
I anticipate that it will be
quite another sort of scene
of another clime and a lot of
boys very sick. It is so cool
here to what it was in Washington
that I almost felt uncomfortable
in the change, but it
seemed home like-Chicago like
and that was comforting.

Ah, I shall never lose my love
for Illinois, she is first in
my heart what ever of beauty
of tropic lands may have
before my eyes. I shall hold
her cornfields and meadows
above all else.  It is the soil
of many recollections that
will never fade: and it is my
home.

 On the bosom of the wide

ocean, I cannot think that it
is somewhere here that Mrs.
Osgood and her son sleep till
a time when the resurrection 
shall take place. Ah, the
gray old ocean as well as the
rock bound shore shall yield
many. -  about 5 P.M.

The Catalina a captured
Spanish cruiser just passed
us, she is a real beauty for
being built by the Spaniards.
Another war ship own make
came in also they saluted us
and we answered with a blast
of whistles and horn. The
Vendome is her name and
she has guns on each side
one fore and aft. I am told that
the "Resolute" is our own ship
and not a captured Spanish
boat.

 8.45 P.M. After tea and

having been on deck the
breeze is stiff and invigorating

I who have allways had a
longing for the ocean am now
testing its hospitality and find it
charming. I have not been
the first atome? sea sick yet,
some who have been on the sea
often have had several unpleasant
sensations. I saidÂ :"I will
not be sick." now we shall
see what determination will
do. this is only scarcely part
of a day yet. That reminds 
me of the story of the woman
who said to the Doctor, "O
Doctor whenever I put my
hand to my head it ackes so."
he said, "Well don't put your

hand to your head then," That 
applys to more than one case.
Well, am out on the rolling
deep, the sea runs beautifully.
I cannot make myself to
comprehend that I am nearly 
2000 miles from Chicago
I have come with such
speed that I can hardly
feel I am not at the distance.
We do not know what
a day may bring forth, I
have accustomed myself to
many changes.  I am not now
the least bit homesick. I had
an attack of that feeling at
Washington D C but have now
met so many pleasant nurses
that not a trace of any

home longing remains. I would
though that could communicate
with my friends verbaly, but
blessed be the art of writing. We 
can express our thoughts if it
be at a long range. It was
a beautiful bit of sunset
in the clouds this evening and
I exclaimed at seeing it. A
woman who rooms across 
from myself and roommate
came in and said "You will see
beautiful sights in the tropics, the
sunsets are grand." We nurses
are very jolly, it seems like
picknic excursion rather than
ought else. Well we'll take
the sunshine while we can.
I live to laugh and grow fat.

Wednesday 20 "July 2.45 P.M.
We are below Cape henry
opposite the South Carolina
coast. We are 40 miles from
Shore. I as went in quet
of the Engineer or the
man who knows route
to find out when we would
be near Cape Hatteras. He
invited me into the cabin
room and traced out on
several maps our course.
He was so kind and pleasant.
told me that at 10 tonight
we would be at Cape H-
then we will cross the
Gulf Stream and it may
be a little rough. The

journey thus far has been
smooth with beautiful
sunshine. There is scarcely
a ripple or white cap on
the water and the boat
goes very evenly making
between 20 and 25 knots an
hour.

 We have seen 

several vessels at a distance
but no land is visible. I do
love the ocean it has a 
peculiar color that shimmers
in the sun - a mixture
of blue and green and
gray I shall bathe if there
will be any chance of being
near the coast.

 The ocean, how I have

said, I would love to see it and

feel its breeze. Nolan, "the 
man without a country" knew
no other home and in its
fair phases it is most
kindly, bearing you on its
bosom like a trusting child.
but in its fury who knows
what its lashings
may be like.

 If I die in the service

of my country, I ask nothing
but to be wrapped in the
flag. I think it is a 
lovely thing to see it float
from the mast and to know
that we are under its service.
Three of us girls got silk
fogs and draped our hats.
We purchased them in

Washington DC and then as
well as at New York we
were supreme attraction at
the time. We have the
favors shown us as if we
were a royal party on tour
and be it known, that we
women engaged by the 
Government in war our
names will go down in history 
as the brave who sacrificed
all for their land. The pictures
of the nurses were taken on
board the steamer by one of the
staff of "Leslies Weekly"
but I could not be there
as I was trying to locate
my package which the
Adams express company
failed to produce,

The Captain informed me 
that we would reach Santiago,
Eastern Cuba by Saturday night
or Sunday morning. There is 
about 100 crew on board
the "Resolute" one of the 
Old Dominion 
steamers, but the "Resolute"
is quite modern and a beauty.

 There is a Cuban Doctor on 

board. I have not yet learned his
name though he has raised 
his hat to me. One of the 
nurses is applying herself
to the study of French. Her
name is Packard and is from
Iowa. After she had studied
a while she turned to me and
said I guess I'll teach you
Spanish now. She said
something which I said

after her, and the Cuban Doctor
sitting close by corrected her
where upon we all laughed
and she agreed not to
teach till she herself knew
the language. We have a 
good time among ourselves,
for being strangers thrown
to-gether in such a manner.
Nor manner, but cause. It 
is growing so much warmer
than yesterday, when we were
going out of the New York
Harbor. What will it be when
we reach Cuba, but I am a
warm weather sort of a creature
and shall not disturb me so
much. I shall no doubt think
of your cooling lake winds
in Chicago and sigh for a 
whiff of that clime.

There is a very jolly traveler
on board. I mistook him for
an officer and asked him
some questions. He told me he
was a guest and murderer,
meaning that he had several
connections with Spaniards.
I shall continue my information
later on.

 The expanse of the ocean from

horizon is a magnificent
view. There is not a white cap on
the ocean anywhere and the sailors
say there has never been a smoother
sea. Some of the sailors are barefoot
enjoying no doubt to dispense with those
"prison cells of pride". The Steamer
cuts through the salt water making
a pure white foam, I am giving myself 
up to the Luxury of thoroughly
enjoying this trip - sitting on deck
gazing off on the broad waste of water.

Have not seen any whales yet
nor sharks, some sea gulls
have hovered over the water
and a few porpoises have
[ ] come up and dived
around making the sea foam.

 Thursday 10 A.M.
 Last night at 11 o'clock

we passed the light house
of Cape Hatteras. I remained
on deck untill 1/2 past eleven
when I went down to my cabin.
It was growing rough as we
were crossing the Gulf Stream
to-day there are white caps
on the water and it is a 
decidedly cobalt blue - lighter
than a sapphire blue.

The Cuban Doctor spoke to me
to-night and said he hoped we
would all be assigned one
hospital. I am sure we are
all mutual and cooperative
in our work.

 Will you please send 

this to Anna when you
get through with it? I feel
very could about not being
sea sick, have not been
sea sick yet, have been
on deck all the time and
have enjoyed it immensely.

 You do not know what a

beautiful blue the ocean is.
Yours with love Amy - We have
traveled about 500 miles and are about
half way.

On Board the U.S.S. Resolute
Santiago Bay July 25 '98
My Dear Mother:

 While we are here waiting

I will write you a few
words.

 We reached Guantanamo 

Bay Sunday noon
Saluted Admiral Sampson's
flagship New York. The
first ship to salute is
was the Iowa.

 We remained at Guantanamo

until this morning.

when we steamed out at
7. After 2 hours
time we came into
Santiago Bay. Saw Old
Morro Castle punctured
by the shells from the
Navy. Saw the Maria
Theresa sunk on the 
shore and not far
from her inward
lay our Merrimac,
but she was sunk 
in such a position
that it did not
blockade the bay at
all.

 The banks of Santiago

is beautifully wooded,
with banana trees and

The Spanish Magnolia a
large tree bearing beautiful
scarlet blossoms.

 The Town of Santiago 

lies on the bank of the
bay and is exposed to
shot and shell.  The town
is quite abandoned
and the people have
no food. The houses
are low, one story 
made of yellow clay.

 Our Resolute is owned

by the Government.
She is a beautiful
boat. 350 feet long,
between 3 and 4000 tonnage,
draws 20 feet water

her speed is 15 knots per
hour. When I think of
where I am and not a
week has elapsed it
makes me reel at the
thought. We are so
far from each other
but O I am so glad
to come and do some
good. We have on board
5,000 tents, among
the hosts of other supplies
for our army need. 

 It is so funny to

see the pelicans
plunge into the water
for fish in the bay.
The bay is very filthy.
The refuse of centuries
has been washed down
over [      ] lovingly your daughter Adieu

here. Captain Easton asked several of us
nurses into the upper cabin, where the 
air is degrees cooler, then he ordered
ginger ale for us and told us tales of his
travels. He has sailed for 35 years in all
lands and seen many people. He is such
a perfect gentleman and we have fared
so well that we nurses all drew up
resolutions of thanks and each signed
her name. The surgeons and physicians
signed theirs. The bay is so shallow
that we have to be take over in boats.
We stay in the Resolute until morning
when we disembark for Siboney
over the hills. Lovingly, your daughter Amy

My address is 

 Miss Amy Eleanor Wingreen
                 Contract Nurse
     Siboney, Cuba
 care Major Sommers
                   War Department

On Cuban seas
Monday A.M. 9.15 July 25, 1898
On Board USS Resolute
at 7.30 we steamed out of
Guantanamo Bay bade adieu to Admiral
Sampsons Schleys and Watson's
fleets. Sunday night - last night
was a might lovely was a time in the 
life of each who so happily
enjoyed the privilege of
seeing and hearing that to which
the eyes of a world are turned.
i.e. the United States Fleet.
Admiral Sampson's fleet is
in one Squadron, Admiral
Schley's in our squadron, and
Watson's in another. From the
New York, Admiral Sampsons
ship, the flagship came sounds
of music over the water, the
night made sacred for the
Sabbath day is holy. The lights
from all the different ships

Santiago de Cuba is the most fertile
of any place which we have seen of
Cuban soil.  The hills are covered
with trees, and old sand fort looms
up before us all the places are
situated on the cliffy shore.
[ ] near the mouth of the Bay
is an old Cuban town or village it
lies high on a plateau, banana
trees and the Spanish Magnolia grow
around it. The Bay is shallow and
a Cuban pilot has taken the charge
of the "Resolute" to lead her up into
the Bay. Captain Eaton has not 
that responsibility. Palmetto trees
are abundant, they are a sort of palm.

 It is truly worth a good

deal of ones life to be privileged to
see this famed spot. It is a privilege
which I can hardly realize as yet.
But when I stop to think that I am
such a distance from the shores of the
United States and add to that my Illinois

and steps are cut into the cliff
leading up to the castle. Marks
show where it has been shelled.
The Virginians crew, here met their death 
but, then, Hobson here also was released.
The forts around on the shore below
are quite deserted. The "Maria
Theresa" a Spanish gun boat lies
on her side on the bank in the
mud embedded where she sunk.
Two guns are noticeable and abandoned
sailors clothing strewn on the deck
side which is not under water.
Here a pace in side the "Maria
Theresa" lies our Merrimac she
is submerged so that only the
top of the Masts and smoke stack
are visible. As we enter the bay
we see banana tress and the Spanish
Magnolia tree which
bears a brilliant red blossom
covering nearly all of the tree.

Santiago De Cuba is the most fertile
of any place which we have seen of
Cuban soil. The hills are covered
with trees, and old sand fort looms
up before us all the places are
situated on the cliffy shore.
beyond near the mouth of the Bay
is an old Cuban town or village it
lies high on a plateau, banana 
trees and the Spanish Magnolia grow
around it. The Bay is shallow and
a Cuban pilot has taken the charge
of the "Resolute" to lead her up into
the Bay. Captain Eaton has not
that responsibility. Palmetto trees 
are abundant, they are a sort of palm.

 It is truly worth a good

deal of one's life to be privileged to
see this famed spot.  It is a privilege
which I can hardly realize as yet.
But when I stop to think that I am
such a distance from the shores of the
United States and add to that my Illinois

home I know that I am indeed in
a far distant clime. The Eastern 
portion of Cuba is much farther
off than Havana would be from
home. The distance from 
New York to Santiago is vastly
greater than from N.Y. to Liverpool
where I know that, I not only feel
that I have gone to Europe but
beyond into a farther region.

 This is a glorious moment

to note the place where Cervera's fleet
was bottled up and where our noble
Hobson sunk the Merrimac.  To
behold it! Ye Gods, the moments are
supreme!! The transports which carried
our soldier boys from Tampa lie
about the Bay and I am privileged to
view this with my own eyes.

 A pelican flies out on the

water, it flies like a sea gull.

 The "New York Heral" boat salutes

us and is the first to do so.

 I see beyond the slopes of the 

shore mountains and it is said
that they are far into the interior
the air is so clear that distance
is great.

 And, here we see the city (as 

they call it but looking more like a
huddled together village out of date)
of Santiago on the banks. In the
interior I see the theater and the
spires of a Church save for that, 
there is nothing about the place
worth much.  The houses are built of
yellow clay and are unsubstantial
looking. The town has the appearance of
some ancient community out
of the early history of man.

We had our pictures taken on board
the "Resolute" first the group of
nurses, then the Surgeons and Physicians. 
I shall give my address
to the gentleman who took them
and see if he will not send a 
copy here. I do not think you
will know me because my hair
is cut and I had I felt a very
unnatural excruciating look on
my face at that moment. But 
down into history we go as the
first band of women enlisted into
the Government of the United States
of America. It is a moment to
live for, to feel, that some life
may be saved by us; some father,
son, or husband will be returned
to his own by our skill of nursing.
I have taken the oath to serve

faithfully my country and the office
under which I serve, and for my
flag, and for my country, I shall have
strength to bear privations, toil
and whatever may come up in our
army life. Our Major Summers
M.D. gave the nurses a little
talk which we love him the better for, he
told us that army life was a hard
life, that army nursing was not what
hospital nursing was, that army

Dear Sister Anna:
When I remember how I wanted to go to Cuba
or to this far off shore to be valiant in this
cause I think that our own fervent wishes
some times had better not be granted by a
loving and wise providence, think not that
I would shirk when duty calls, for that I
truly would not when it is well and
advisable. It may be that in after years when
a gray haired woman I may be able to shine
around some eager circle of friends that my
vanity may be rewarded and, for that, my
experience in a land of desolation and misery
may have found a response outside of my own
self. But O we haven't anything to work with, no
ice, but are promised that an ice plant will

be erected and we will have it. I was given a little
this A.M. as big as a dinner plate and [ ].
Truly it is a beautiful thing to have valor and die for
one's country after you know there has been some thought
about you to live and provision made
it however is of another form and color
to encounter. I wonder if they know back there in
Washington when they wind up with iced teas and ice cream that a little plain ice here might save a mother's boy, but I can't dwell on it.
The facilities for hospital work is
so meager and the odds of climate so much against
us that we work like soldiers sent to the
front without ammunition. We have fevers and
heat prostration by the cores. Thermic fever
predominates and the poor boys, strong and noble -
mothers and fathers own lads, fall before the tropic
sun never to recover. We work on hopefully for the
fortunate ones who have the constitution and strive
hard for those who have not. The town of Siboney
is situated on the Sea coast with scarcely any harbor
yet so shallow is the little [ ] that we had
to be rowed ashore in small boats about 1 1/2 miles
from the landing. Siboney is by far the most
desirable of either Santiago or Guantanamo

us and the ocean at our feet from which we get strong

is therefore the two elements to combat, only a native can
endure it. The ground on which our tents and all the 
tents of this camp was the old town of Siboney which
was burned. The gardens adjoining are half blasted
but the banana plants shoot up from the parent
stalks. From Cape Maysi all along the coast of

a more luxurious tone. The country is very mountainous
and rocky although in the interior it is said to be
fertile, having valleys and table land. There is no enterprise
of any kind, a railway from Siboney to Santiago runs
along the sea cliff and that is as antiquated as the
days of Columbus himself running at the rate of an
army mule. They use mules here, there are some
horses but the mules stand the work and climate

as we were not detailed then, it was a walk

of about 8 miles coming and going. The road was made by our
men cutting through the wood which is dense with an

the future Cuban generations that the people and the
land will be more promising. As yet, what
the promise will be to any class or people

Forty Days in the Wilderness
or
Siboney, Cuba as it was in July & August 1898.
by Amy Eleanor Wingreen
It was at the close of a Sunday evening about the
middle of July 1898. that the United States Ship
Resolute steamed into Guantanamo Bay. The
Resolute was laden with Government supplies,
Surgeons, and nurses, for the American soldiers
stricken in Siboney. The American Yellow Fever
Camp of the tropics. The old man of the Sea had
been in a most pleasant frame of mind and
favored us with the most delightful weather
for our voyage. The beautiful Resolute so

heavily loaded with the various supplies,
soldiers from New York, tents, medicines,
food and hospital necesities with the
Physicians & nurses on board, filled the
protected ships to the utmost and she
plowed the waves steadily into the
Cuban waters. We saluted Admiral Sampson,
and the American Fleet at Guantanamo.
Admiral Sampson's squadron, and Schleys
squadron, and Watson's squadron, each
lay by itself in a group, yet so arranged
as to form a crescent in the crescent shaped
bay. We cast anchor near the Iowa, and
Captain Evans was the first to salute us.
We saw by the decending rays of the sun Army
tents on the shore of Guananamo, and the
American flag floating over the Cuban port,
and the banner of freedom flew from every
ship mast of that splendid navy; We were
filled with awe, and admiration, by the noble
sight of American battleships which like Sentinels were
ready for faction, for war was the supreme thought

of the hour; War with American and Spain
was at its height: The stars glittered from that
most beautiful of skies, in tropic waters. The
sky and the sea blend in most perfect
unison. Strains of music floated over the
bay, it came from the New York, Admiral
Sampson's flagship. "America," 'The Star Spangled
Banner." "The Battle Cry of Freedom," and "Nearer
My God to Thee" filled our mind with thoughts
of repose and safety.
It was Monday morning, the
stars still shone from the clear sky, and the
lights from the fleet lit up the Bay;
small boats were plying to and fro; We were
waiting for sun rise over the hills: It was a

It is Sunday, the weeks go by so rappidly the hours are full, and each day seems like a blue Monday, with the exception of now and then one who seems like a sun beam on the place, the boys all bear their suffering so cheerfully that is is a pleasure to do for them.

The good news was like the visiting of a good angel and every one was anxious to be among those who would be considered well enough to be numbered among the convalescents to go.  The able soldiers arose and dressed early and went out tot the mess line instead of being served in the ward, the more weak ones showed their enthusiasm by sitting on the cats for hours at a time to demonstrate that they were quite well enough to be counted among the well ones. THE CHICAGO CHRONICLE, THURSDAY MORNING. SEPTEMBER 29, 1898.
NURSE IN FROM CUBA
Miss Amy E. Wingreen Returns to Chicago from Siboney.
Only National Emergency Association Representative There.
Forty Men of This City Cared For by Her at Front.
Will Tell of Her Experiences at a Military Reunion Tomorrow.
Miss Amy Eleanor Wingreen , nurse of the National Emergency association, has returned from Cuba.  Miss Wingreen, the association's only representative in Cuba, was stationed at Siboney in the fever hospital, where she had entire charge of from twenty to seventy fever stricken soldiers.  She left Chicago July 15, and from the time she landed in Cuba until she reached Chicago again she was on duty from sixteen to eighteen hours each day.  The extra time she spent in writing to mothers whose sons had died, many of them from despair of ever reaching home and friends again.  Hours were spent in listening to the last prayer of fever wasted lads and in giving a last kindly word to sufferers who begged protection from imagined harms.  All these left little time in which the nurse might rest.
Notwithstanding the hardships, the meager fare of hard-tack and coffee and the danger from the fevers, Miss Wingreen has come home with a record of not a single sick minute.  She used every precaution to avoid illness.  She had her hair cut close to her head, adopted the short cotton skirt and lived as nearly as possible according to the customs of the tropics.  The emergency uniform of gray and blue woolen cloth was left in Atlanta, and nothing but necessaries were made a part of the small bundle which she was allowed to take with her to Cuba.
Miss Wingreen was transferred to Port Rico when the hospital at Siboney was abandoned, but when she reached Montauk she decided that she was in need of rest and obtained her discharge from service.  
Forty Chicago boys were under her care in Siboney and of those who reached home she has a complete list and is now busily visiting them.  She has planned to give a reception for them soon at the home of her sister, Mrs. J. N. Anderson, 238 Lincoln Park boulevard, and, although some of them are again sick and at the city hospital, she hopes to greet nearly thirty at her home.
In the meantime the La Salle Avenue Baptist church is to give a military reunion, at which Miss Wingreen will related her impressions of the war.  The affair will be held tomorrow evening, from 8 until 11 o'clock.
THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1898.
NURSE WINGREEN RETURNS.
Chicago Woman Tells of the Suffering of Soldiers in Siboney and Camp Wikoff.
Miss Amy Eleanor Wingreen, the only woman nurse from Chicago in the yellow fever camp at Sibney during the heights of the epidemic, returned to this city on Tuesday, and is stopping with her parents, 238 Lincoln Park boulevard.
"The newspapers cannot begin to tell of the terrible suffering that was endured by the poor soldiers in Cuba," said Miss Wingreen last night.  "There were ten women nurses on the Resolute, the boat by which I reached Santiago.  Two of them remained in Santiago and the other eight were sent to the yellow fever camp at Siboney.  When we reached there we found 3,000 sick soldiers, and we were the only women nurses there.  As soon as the sick soldiers recovered they turned in and helped us nurse their comrades."
Miss Wingreen was at Sibney thirty-three days.  She then returned to Camp Wikoff and of the conditions there she made this significant statement:
"When the returning soldiers on the Berkshire were released from quarantine, President McKinley witnessed the debarkation.  At the sight of the emaciated soldiers he wept."
